channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: New evidence suggests 'Screaming Woman' mummy died in pain
item.description: The mummy is believed to be a relative of Senmut, an architect who worked during the reign of ancient Egypt’s most powerful female leader, Queen Hatshepsut. Senmut’s final years also remain a mystery.
item.content:encoded:
The mummy is believed to be a relative of Senmut, an architect who worked during the reign of ancient Egypt’s most powerful female leader, Queen Hatshepsut. Senmut’s final years also remain a mystery.

(Image credit: Saleem and El-Merghani)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: 'Grandmas Against the Far-Right' hope to change AfD supporters' minds in Germany
item.description: The far-right Alternative for Germany party is leading the polls ahead of state elections. A group called "Grandmas Against the Far-Right" is trying to get German voters to shun the AfD party.
item.content:encoded: The far-right Alternative for Germany party is leading the polls ahead of state elections. A group called "Grandmas Against the Far-Right" is trying to get German voters to shun the AfD party.
item.dc:creator: Esme Nicholson

item.title: Olympic champ Ryan Crouser goes for gold again with an intricate approach to shot put
item.description: American Ryan Crouser has turned the shot put into a science. As he goes for his third Olympic gold in a row, he keeps tweaking ideas of rotation, radius and speed and utilizes computer mechanics.
item.content:encoded: American Ryan Crouser has turned the shot put into a science. As he goes for his third Olympic gold in a row, he keeps tweaking ideas of rotation, radius and speed and utilizes computer mechanics.
item.dc:creator: Steve Futterman

item.title: Video game performers are on strike — and AI is the sticking point
item.description:
If you're not entrenched in the world of video games, you might not realize how much real actors have to do with modern gaming.

They provide everything from lines of dialogue, to portraying heroes and villains, to performing stunts – all of this bringing video games characters to life.

Some of the biggest game studios rely on voice and performance capture artists, and all this adds up to big bucks. The video game industry made close to $185 billion last year.

But video game performers whose human performances become computer data, are especially vulnerable to being replaced by generative AI.

Which is why they're now on strike.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
If you're not entrenched in the world of video games, you might not realize how much real actors have to do with modern gaming.

They provide everything from lines of dialogue, to portraying heroes and villains, to performing stunts – all of this bringing video games characters to life.

Some of the biggest game studios rely on voice and performance capture artists, and all this adds up to big bucks. The video game industry made close to $185 billion last year.

But video game performers whose human performances become computer data, are especially vulnerable to being replaced by generative AI.

Which is why they're now on strike.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

item.title: The fastest 10,000m runner still reigns, and U.S. steps onto podium after 12 years
item.description: World record holder Joshua Cheptegei of Uganda looked up to four-time Olympic medalist Kenenisa Bekele as a kid. He just stole the Ethiopian's Olympic record. Grant Fisher won bronze for the U.S.
item.content:encoded:
World record holder Joshua Cheptegei of Uganda looked up to four-time Olympic medalist Kenenisa Bekele as a kid. He just stole the Ethiopian's Olympic record. Grant Fisher won bronze for the U.S.

(Image credit: Petr David Josek)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Harris courts Latino voters in Arizona
item.description: Democrats believe they have an opportunity to make inroads with an important voting bloc in swing state Arizona: Latinos.
item.content:encoded: Democrats believe they have an opportunity to make inroads with an important voting bloc in swing state Arizona: Latinos.

item.title: The cost of putting on the Olympics is making it harder to find host cities
item.description: The Olympic Games almost always comes with a substantial financial burden for a host city. But are cost-benefit analysts too simplistic for how we evaluate their impact?
item.content:encoded: The Olympic Games almost always comes with a substantial financial burden for a host city. But are cost-benefit analysts too simplistic for how we evaluate their impact?
item.dc:creator: Darian Woods

item.title: The 100-year history of sex testing female athletes in elite sports
item.description: "Tested" from NPR’s podcast Embedded and CBC in Canada examines the 100-year history of the practice of sex testing female athletes in elite sports.
item.content:encoded: "Tested" from NPR’s podcast Embedded and CBC in Canada examines the 100-year history of the practice of sex testing female athletes in elite sports.

item.title: Sorority sister of Kamala Harris remembers her as the 'consummate college student'
item.description: Before any public office, Kamala Harris went to Washington, D.C., to study at Howard University. Jill Louis, class of '87, joined Alpha Kappa Alpha at the same time as Harris.
item.content:encoded: Before any public office, Kamala Harris went to Washington, D.C., to study at Howard University. Jill Louis, class of '87, joined Alpha Kappa Alpha at the same time as Harris.
item.dc:creator: Marc Rivers

item.title: U.S. swimmers falter again on Day 7 of Olympics, winning a single silver medal
item.description: The U.S. swim team entered Paris confident after a strong showing in national trials. But the American team's stars struggled again on Friday night as swimmers from Australia and France dominated.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. swim team entered Paris confident after a strong showing in national trials. But the American team's stars struggled again on Friday night as swimmers from Australia and France dominated.

(Image credit: Adam Pretty)
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann
